awd_titl_txt: MRI: ACQUISITION OF A MULTICOLLECTOR-ICP-MASS SPECTROMETER FOR MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH AND TEACHING AT NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY
awd_abstract_narration:
NSF funds will be used to acquire a multicollector-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (MC-ICPMS). The MC-ICPMS will promote understanding of environmental challenges for rural Arizona, including remediation of areas that have been polluted from mining, sourcing and transport/fate of anthropogenic pollutants, volcanic hazards, and evidence for - and ecosystem responses to - global change. It will improve STEM-related teaching and research training at a university that serves a large rural Arizona and Native American population, as well as a large Hispanic community. The diverse research capabilities enabled by the new MC-ICPMS will be integral to the new comprehensive, integrative, and distinctive Earth and Environmental Systems Ph.D. program. 

The MC-ICPMS will advance research and training in isotope chemistry that spans the Geology, Chemistry/Biochemistry, Anthropology, Biology, Environmental Sciences and Forestry programs. With this instrument, the assembled investigators and their students will obtain high precision isotopic data for geochemical and geochronological investigations across the mass spectrum. The new MC-ICPMS will play a vital role in advancing the research objectives of at least 15 professional scientists and their students, including advancing knowledge related to: (1) the assembly and eruption of magmas responsible for explosive, sometime giant, events; (2) anthropogenic pollution; (3) landscape and tectonic evolution; and (4) large earthquakes and periodic fluid migration from depth.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

The goal of this project was to acquire and successfully operate a new multi-collector inductively-coupled mass spectrometer (MC-ICPMS) for Northern Arizona University (NAU). A MC-ICPMS is a versatile instrument that enables researchers to measure the relative proportions of different nuclear configurations of an element of interest. Observed variations can, in turn, be used for geologic dating and for understanding how elements behave in earth systems. Of particular note, the acquired MC-ICPMS has and will continue to advance outcomes for society through a greater understanding of the behavior of trace metals in the environment, and through development of human resources at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

ACQUISITION: A Nu Plasma 3 MC-ICPMS was acquired through this grant and is the centerpiece of the newly created NAU Plasma Facility. Instrument installation and training occurred in Fall 2017. Acquisition of this instrument and the human resources assembled to support and capitalize on it enabled the facility to acquire complementary new instruments that extended its capabilities.

Lab supervision and management: The Plasma Facility was a major factor in successful recruitment of Dr. Laura Wasylenki to the position of Associate Professor at NAU. Wasylenki investigates metal stable isotope geochemistry in geological, environmental, and biological settings. She holds a joint appointment in the School of Earth and Sustainability and in Chemistry and Biochemistry, and is a major stakeholder in the NAU Plasma Facility. A lab manager for the Plasma Facility was supported by funds from this grant and matching funds committed by NAU over the course of two years. The lab manager performed routine lab operations, including technique development, maintenance and troubleshooting of the MC-ICPMS, and assisting students with their laboratory work. They worked with NAU Health and Safety to ensure that the laboratory complied with federal, state, and university safety laws and regulations (e.g., development and implementation of chemical hygiene procedures, assessment and minimization of hazards and risks, and developing emergency protocols).

Development of technical infrastructure: A number of developments to the infrastructure of mass spectrometry facility significantly improved the facility?s capabilities but necessarily delayed completion of this project. NAU opted to renovate the facility?s instrument laboratory for the new MC-ICPMS, with a plan for instrument layout designed by Nu Instruments. NAU also decided to renovate an existing laboratory to support chemical, material, and sample preparations after funding was received for the MC-ICP-MS, a process that required three years (2015-2018). A new 200 ft2 lab for processing samples that are especially sensitive to environmental contamination was completed near the end of 2021. Recognition of the value of results that can be acquired on the MC-ICPMS helped with further acquisition of a different type of mass spectrometer, one capable of determining element concentrations (Agilent 7900), with NAU funding. Also acquired in a successful proposal to NAU?s Technology and Research Initiative Fund was a Photon Machines 193 nm excimer laser. The laser enables the lab to pursue certain types of isotopic analyses within small geologic/environmental domains without sample processing.

Technique development: Methods for a variety of isotopic analyses can now be performed in the Plasma Facility. Of special note are isotopic analyses of tungsten, nickel, and uranium, elements that have been strongly influenced by human activities and can pose environmental hazards. Results obtained using these techniques have been presented at five international conferences.

BROADER IMPACTS

A postdoctoral researcher and three graduate students (all of them females) were recruited to NAU to undertake projects that rely on results obtained by MC-ICPMS analyses. These individuals furthered their research training and professional development, and have coauthored publications arising from their work. Both undergraduates and graduate student have benefited from use of the Plasma Facility for laboratory experiences related to their coursework in geochemistry. Two of the principal investigators also led a graduate seminar during Spring 2017 focused on applications of the new MC-ICPMS. A strategic aspect of the seminar was to include faculty members from diverse research areas who could benefit from use of the new lab facility.
